results.title: Dead centre
results.brief_description: There are many kinds of centres: centres of dart boards, baby health centres, fathers who are the centres of their family. There is also the centre of the road: the drivers who stay on it are likely to end up in the dead centre - the Coroner’s Court.

results.title: Dead birds
results.brief_description: An interpretation of the life and customs of the Dani people of Central West Irian, who exist in continuous warfare between neighbouring villages, reduced to ritualised alternating attacks. Robert Gardner’s study of the life and customs of the Baliem Valley people of western New Guinea. Explores the nature of primitive warfare and its motivations. Shows traditional mutilation and death customs as well as food production, housing, mythology, clothing, ornament, and art.

results.title: De Renoir a Picasso
results.creator_credit: Jean Van Raemdonck and Paul Haesaerts
results.brief_description: Part of the “Art et cinema” series, this film presents a study and comparison of the characteristics of Renoir the sensualist, Seurat, the intellectual, and Picasso, the instructive artist, the three main inspirational sources for modern French art. The soft, rounded forms of Renoir are related to the Greek ideal of physical beauty, Seurat’s severe simplification are shown to echo Byzantine style; and Picasso’s distortions are traced back to similar experiments in primitive art.

results.title: De Gaulle: republican monarch
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson
results.brief_description: Part of the “Leaders of the 20th century: portraits of power” this episode begins in 1958 when Charles De Gaulle is called to lead France after a civil war. De Gaulle forms the Fifth Republic and institutes a presidential style of government for ten years bringing political, economic and financial stability to FRance until he is forced out by waves of unrest in 1968.

results.title: De Gaulle: force of character
results.creator_credit: Nielsen-Ferns, New York Times Productions and Don Thompson
results.brief_description: Part of the “Leaders of the 20th century: portraits of power” series, this episode shows how Charles De Gaulle, through his determination and force of character, was able to provide a focal point for the Free French during the occupation years in France. Incorporates footage of De Gaulle in England and North Africa during the war years. Narrated by Henry Fonda.

results.title: De Facto
results.brief_description: An animated film to promote discussion. The ceremony of commissioning a new building is about to begin, but first it must be painted white to match its twin, which is located nearby. The people gather, the officials appear, the drummer beats his drum in noisy salute to the magnificent new building… and the building collapses. Who is to blame? The architect? The bricklayer? The carpenter? The painter? Finally a decision is reached. It was the drummer’s fault. The angry officials descend on the hapless drummer, take his drum and stomp on it. A loud triumphant cheer rings out from the crowd… and the second building falls down!

results.title: Days of destruction
results.brief_description: Examines and chronicles the January, 1973 eruption of the volcano Eldfell on the Icelandic island of Aeimaey. Shows how scientists studied the eruption and documents the civil defence personnel and towns people as they attempted to save buildings from approaching lava flow. Depicts the evacuation of the 5,000 inhabitants, both by air and sea. Graphically captures scenes of bellowing craters, flowing lava and burning and collapsing buildings.

results.title: Days of being wild
results.creator_credit: Rover Tang, In-gear Film and Wong
results.brief_description: Wong Kar-Wai has become one of the most respected and influential filmmakers in the world since coming to prominence in the 1990s. He is a highly imaginative film stylist, whose sensuous mise-en-scene, radical editing and fragmented narratives seem aptly appropriate for an increasingly decentered postmodern world. This early film, “Days of Being Wild”, is set in 1960 and examines the relationships Yuddi (Leslie Cheung), has with three women; his courtesan adopted mother, and his two very different girlfriends (Maggie Cheung and Carina Lau). Spoilt, pampered, rich and decadent, Yuddi seems to have everything he could ask for in life, but his one real desire remains unfulfilled; to discover the identity of his natural mother. Set in a searing hot Hong Kong summer, “Days of Being Wild” is a highly erotic and cynical examination of a young bourgeois man, devoid of self-discipline, who is able to remain a “boy” through his exploitation of adoring women. In this early film, the plush warm lighting, the rich cinematography and the exuberant, playful editing already reveal the spectacular craft and the romantic sensibility that distinguishes all of Kar-Wai’s films. In Cantonese with English subtitles.
